verses.text: First of all, then, I urge that petitions, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people,
verses.comment: Paul encourages Christians to pray widely and intercede for others. The mention of 'intercessions' points toward the practice of asking God on behalf of others, which reflects the role of prayer in uniting people to God's will.

verses.text: for kings and all who are in positions of authority, so that we may lead a peaceful and quiet life in all godliness and dignity.
verses.comment: Praying for rulers expresses a desire for stability and peace, which helps the Church flourish and Christians to live out holiness. Recognizing legitimate authority is foundational to Christian order and reflects a spiritual submission.

verses.text: This is good and pleasing in the eyes of God our Savior,
verses.comment: God desires our prayers for all people, demonstrating the universal scope of God's saving will. The term 'Savior' here emphasizes Jesus’s divine role in salvation.

verses.text: who wants all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth.
verses.comment: God’s will is for everyone’s salvation, rejecting any notion of a purely exclusive predestination. This verse affirms the universality of the gospel while implying the need for the Church's ministry to guide people to truth.

verses.text: For there is one God, and one mediator between God and humanity—the man Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Jesus Christ uniquely bridges God and humans, emphasizing His role as mediator. 'One God' and 'one mediator' highlight the unity of the faith, and the passage supports the practice of intercession through Christ’s work.

verses.text: who gave himself as a ransom for all—the testimony at the proper time.
verses.comment: Christ’s self-sacrifice is foundational, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies of redemption (Isaiah 53:10–12). The phrase 'ransom for all' reaffirms universal atonement through Christ.

verses.text: For this I was appointed a herald and an apostle—I speak the truth, I am not lying—a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and truth.
verses.comment: Paul’s authority as apostle to the nations is divinely commissioned, underscoring the transmission of apostolic teaching as essential to Christian faith.

verses.text: I want the men in every place to pray, lifting up holy hands without anger or quarreling.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes purity and unity in worship. Lifting hands symbolize surrender and holiness (cf. Psalm 134:2), stressing the spiritual disposition required for true prayer.

verses.text: Likewise, I want the women to adorn themselves in respectable clothing, with modesty and self-control—not with braids, gold, pearls, or expensive clothes,
verses.comment: This instruction stresses inner virtues over external appearance. The call to modesty and self-control promotes spiritual dignity and reflects a life that witnesses to holiness, an invitation to imitate the saints.

verses.text: but with good works, as is proper for women who profess reverence for God.
verses.comment: Good works are highlighted as the true adornment for all Christians; the pursuit of sanctity expressed in daily life reflects faith in action, rooted in the teachings of Christ.

verses.text: Let a woman learn quietly, with full submission.
verses.comment: Paul encourages women’s spiritual education, but under the order and discipline fitting Christian worship. This alludes to the harmonious structure of the Church founded on apostolic authority.

verses.text: I do not permit a woman to teach or have authority over a man, but she is to remain quiet.
verses.comment: This passage prescribes the roles for worship leadership, consistent with apostolic tradition. The structure reflects spiritual order and the unique responsibilities entrusted within the Church.

verses.text: For Adam was formed first, then Eve;
verses.comment: The reference to Genesis underlines order in creation, which Paul uses as a foundation for the roles described within the Church. The design of creation is tied to spiritual symbolism.

verses.text: and Adam was not deceived, but the woman was deceived and became a transgressor.
verses.comment: Paul draws upon the fall narrative to explain his instruction, but this does not diminish the dignity of women; rather, it highlights God’s redemptive plan through both men and women in salvation history.

verses.text: But she will be saved through childbearing—if they continue in faith, love, and holiness, with self-control.
verses.comment: This mysterious verse is best understood spiritually and literally. The mention of childbearing recalls the promise of salvation through Eve’s offspring (Gen. 3:15), ultimately fulfilled in Christ’s incarnation. Continuing in faith, love, and holiness echoes the calling to sanctity for all believers, not by works alone but through the mystery of God working in our lives.
